trans-unit.source: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> consists of both the database engine and an embedded JDBC driver. Applications use JDBC to interact with a database. Applications running on JDK 5 must load the driver in order to work with the database.

seg-source.mrk: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> consists of both the database engine and an embedded JDBC driver.
Applications use JDBC to interact with a database.
Applications running on JDK 5 must load the driver in order to work with the database.

target.mrk: <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> consists of both the database engine and an embedded JDBC driver.
Applications use JDBC to interact with a database.
Applications running on JDK 5 must load the driver in order to work with the database.

trans-unit.source: In an embedded environment, loading the driver also starts <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph>.

seg-source.mrk: In an embedded environment, loading the driver also starts <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph>.

target.mrk: In an embedded environment, loading the driver also starts <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph>.

trans-unit.source: The driver class name for the embedded environment is org.apache.derby.jdbc.EmbeddedDriver.

seg-source.mrk: The driver class name for the embedded environment is org.apache.derby.jdbc.EmbeddedDriver.

target.mrk: The driver class name for the embedded environment is org.apache.derby.jdbc.EmbeddedDriver.

trans-unit.source: In a Java application, you typically load the driver with the static Class.forName method or with the jdbc.drivers system property. For example:

seg-source.mrk: In a Java application, you typically load the driver with the static Class.forName method or with the jdbc.drivers system property.

target.mrk: In a Java application, you typically load the driver with the static Class.forName method or with the jdbc.drivers system property.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information about loading the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> JDBC driver, see "java.sql.Driver interface" in the <cite><ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citref"></ph></cite>.

seg-source.mrk: For detailed information about loading the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> JDBC driver, see "java.sql.Driver interface" in the <cite><ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citref"></ph></cite>.

target.mrk: For detailed information about loading the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> JDBC driver, see "java.sql.Driver interface" in the <cite><ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citref"></ph></cite>.

trans-unit.source: If your application runs on JDK 6 or higher, you do not need to explicitly load the <codeph>EmbeddedDriver</codeph>. In that environment, the driver loads automatically.

seg-source.mrk: If your application runs on JDK 6 or higher, you do not need to explicitly load the <codeph>EmbeddedDriver</codeph>.
In that environment, the driver loads automatically.

target.mrk: If your application runs on JDK 6 or higher, you do not need to explicitly load the <codeph>EmbeddedDriver</codeph>.
In that environment, the driver loads automatically.

trans-unit.source: If your application shuts down Derby or calls the DriverManager.deregisterDriver method, and you then want to reload the driver, call the Class.forName().newInstance() method.

seg-source.mrk: If your application shuts down Derby or calls the DriverManager.deregisterDriver method, and you then want to reload the driver, call the Class.forName().newInstance() method.

target.mrk: If your application shuts down Derby or calls the DriverManager.deregisterDriver method, and you then want to reload the driver, call the Class.forName().newInstance() method.
